abstracts.cdata!:
The Food Crisis Development Support
            Credit Project in Bangladesh along with the Government of
            Bangladesh (GOB) has sought to reduce the impact on the most
            vulnerable groups: (i) food grain, particularly rice, is
            being made available to the poor at subsidized prices; (ii)
            existing safety net programs are being scaled up; (iii) a
            new safety net program, an employment guarantee scheme, has
            been initiated to help people in distressed areas-such as
            those that periodically suffer from extreme food shortages,
            known in the local dialect as Monga-abtain employment during
            lean agricultural periods; and (iv) ensuring the adequate
            and timely availability of farm inputs including seeds,
            fertilizer and diesel to farmers. The FY09 budget has
            significantly increased allocations to assist the poor deal
            with the food crisis. GOB has requested all stakeholders
            including the development partners to assist in this effort.
            The Bank has been requested to provide budget-support under
            its Global Food Response Program (GFW) to assist GOB'S
            measures to maintain macroeconomic stability, ensure food
            security in the immediate short-run, and help those affected
            by rising food prices.
